characters: MISS HELLMAN AND HER VICIOUS SMILE
ARE YOU OUT OF YOUR FUCKING
THEIR FACES IN THE BACK WINDOW
LES ZEROES OUT THE TRIP MILEAGE RECORDER
A MOTORCYCLE COP ACROSS THE STREET
DAD AT THE DOOR TO THE GARAGE
THE PARKING LOT OF A SHAKEY'S
A FEROCIOUS DOG CHAINED ON A PORCH
OUTSIDE THE FRONT OF THE HOUSE
AS HE KICKS OPEN THE DOORS TO THE BAR
THE BUS IS HEADED STRAIGHT FOR THEM
THE HIGHWAY AS JIMI HENDRIX WOULD SEE IT
THE CADDIE GLIDES THROUGH THE AIR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No cars. Swirls of newspapers blow across the street. Suddenly, a YELLOW SCHOOL BUS BECOMES VISIBLE, rising ove hill. As it gets nearer, we feel the ROAR of the engine. The bus is a monster. As it rumbles by us we SEE "SUNNY MEADOWS HIGH SCHOOL" inscribed on the side.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE SCHOOL BUS
dialogues.text: Grimy. Run down. School Bus Hell. Oppressed grey-faced HIGH SCHOOLERS sit round-shouldered, looking out into now land. WE DOLLY SLOWLY ALONG the floor TO REVEAL all the student ankles SHACKLED and CHAINED to their seats. The faint rhy of a FILE RUBBING AGAINST STEEL becomes louder and louder until the CAMERA STOPS ON a student's hands. Seconds away from filing through the lock on his shackle... FREEDOM. The CAMERA TILTS UP TO REVEAL LES ANDERSON, sixteen, mayb seventeen. He's the only kid on the bus with a spark of l left in him. As the bus stops at a RED LIGHT, something catches Les' e

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH A GREASY WINDOW
dialogues.text: He wipes the window, revealing a RED FERRARI 308 GIB park beside the bus, outside a CORNER GROCERY STORE. The T-ROO is off, and all we CAN SEE are the LONGEST, MOST BEAUTIFU LEGS lounging in the passenger seat. A GUY walks away fro the car into the store.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: lecks to the back of the bus, to the REAR DOOR, clearly marked "FOR EMERGENCY USE ONLY." He teeters on the edge o his seat, about to make a move. He looks to the front of bus, at the:

dialogues.speaker: BUS DRIVER
dialogues.text: A maniac: mid-40s, lousy toupee. He's been watching Les i his rearview mirror the entire time. They stare at each other, eye to eye. Les holds his ground. The driver thrus the bus in gear and begins to pull away... away from the Ferrari. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les explodes from his seat, charging for the "emergency door." The kids come to life, watching and screaming with excitement. Les kicks at the door. A RED WARNING LIGHT on the Driver's dash flashes. An ALAR sounds. The Driver looks back, angrily. Then pushes a button. A STEEL BOLT slams across the door. Les slams through the back window -- diving out of the bus onto the street. Les bounces out of a COMMANDO ROLL and runs up the street to Ferrari. The bus does a spectacular BOOTLEGGER'S turn. It's coming back.

dialogues.speaker: LES LOOKS INTO THE FERRARI
dialogues.text: Keys dangle from the ignition. In the passenger seat is t LEGGIEST BLONDE GIRL you've ever seen. The approaching bu builds speed. Les jumps into the car. She smiles, seductively. He smiles back. They're in love. The bus screams towards them. Les turns the ignition, pop the clutch, then squeals into a right turn slicing onto a

dialogues.speaker: QUIET TREE-LINED SUBURBAN STREET
dialogues.text: The bus roars after them, barely making the turn, balanci on two wheels.

dialogues.speaker: LES RACES DOWN THE STREET
dialogues.text: Looks at his speedometer: 70... 75... 80... 85. Maple tre whip by like he's in a rocket ship. AWESOME! He looks up his rearview mirror. It's all yellow. Miraculously, the b is right on his tail. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: A LITTLE BOY DELIVERING PAPERS
dialogues.text: Hops the curb and bicycles across the street. Les, about hit him, yanks the wheel left, practically tearing it off column. The bus bombs by, slicing the front tire off the bike. The LITTLE BOY is left there on his seat, spinning around acrobatically on his back tire.

dialogues.speaker: THE FERRARI
dialogues.text: still trying to lose the bus, streaks down a street, then screeches into: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: NARROW BACK ALLEY
dialogues.text: So narrow they spell it with one "1". The bus slams in, rocking and rebounding off the alley's walls. Dragging po cords and live wires, sparks shoot out from the bus' side Les jams on his brakes, cuts and slides right onto a:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les guns it! A laser beam. With one hand he downshifts to accelerate, with the other, he starts to light the girl's cigarette... She pulls his hand closer to her, looking in his eyes. But WAIT! Up ahead, by a GAS STATION, there's a HUGE PUDD OF WATER. But it's not water. It's GAS! A tank pumps gas into a tanker fuel truck. GAS spews from a ruptured hose. Suddenly, we hear a BORING MONOTONE voice.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: Remember. Be prepared and look ahead. The driver must see the BIG PICTURE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark classroom. The sound of a projector. Flickering light. An instructional film is being shown to a class of DRIVER'S ED STUDENTS. The CAMERA MOVES THROUGH the room a stops in back where we FIND Les Anderson, head on his des fast asleep, resting on his DRIVER'S ED BOOKS.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: «+eIn heavier rain, your tires may begin to 'hydroplane,' ride on the water, rather than the pavement. Don't panic! And especially don't jam on the brakes. Ease your foot off the gas pedal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High speed. There's no avoiding the puddle. Les EASES HIS FOOT off the gas pedal. The Ferrari remains steady as a 1 foot spray of gas erupts on either side of the car. He finishes lighting the girl's cigarette, then casually tos the match out the window. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE BUS
dialogues.text: The driver shifts gears with reckless abandon, charging f the puddle. Suddenly, the puddle ignites. There's a HUGE EXPLOSION. The bus driver JAMMMMS on his brakes. Headed straight for it.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE FERRARI
dialogues.text: Les and the girl hear the explosion and turn around simultaneously. There's no bus, just a huge WALL OF FLAME They smile at each other. They've made it... Les leans ov to kiss her, but suddenly she's not smiling. Her mouth is open in shock. There's terror in her eyes. We hear the RO OF AN ENGINE. Les looks back at the road.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUS IS HEADED STRAIGHT FOR THEM
dialogues.text: about to smash into them. WE HEAR a LOUD HORN which becom a SCHOOL BELL.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: He wakes up, startled. He has sleep marks on one side of face. He looks around, embarrassed. The bell stops. Standing in front of him is the DRIVER'S ED TEACHER, MR. GASKET, the bus driver from the dream. The class is getti up from their desks, leaving. He motions for Les not to move. Leaving the class, A VERY CUTE GIRL turns to Les' twin sister, NATALIE -- she's conservative, bookish.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE GIRL
dialogues.text: (low voice) Does your brother have mono or something? He slept through the entire course.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: No, he's just brain dead. The class empties. Mr. Gasket stands ominously above Les.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GASKET
dialogues.text: (dead serious) Mr. Anderson. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. GASKET (cont'd) It's punks like you the paramedics end up scraping off the roads at four in the morning. (beat) For your own sake and the safety of others, I hope you fail your driver's exam. Les gets up to leave. Gasket signals to stay, then throws him a piece of chalk. Les rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids load into YELLOW SCHOOL BUSES and fancy cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LINES. Blackboards full of "I WILL DRIVE SAFELY. I WILL DRIVE SAFELY..." Les finishes his last one and flies out class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buses and cars begin to pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deserted. Sprinting. Les slides to his locker and quickly unlocks it. An avalanche of books and junk fall onto the floor. He stuffs it back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few kids here and there. Les bombs out of school, jammi papers into his knapsack. He runs down the street after t last departing school bus. He can't catch it. Natalie, inside the bus, smiles at him. He stands in the middle of the road, pissed. We hear a car racing towards him from behind.

dialogues.speaker: IT'S A RED FERRARI
dialogues.text: The one from the dream. T-roof off. Music blares. MERCEDE LANE, the leggy blonde girl from the dream, sits in the passenger seat. PAOLO, her GQ Latin American boyfriend, drives. They're in their own perfect world. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les jumps out of the way as it screams by him. He watches the Ferrari drive off. We hear a bicycle tire SKIDDING along the pavement. He tu to see: A "nut case" on a ten speed stop his thirty foot skid a h away from Les' sneaker. This is DEAN, Les' best friend. H has charm and mischief with a capital M written all over face. They both look back at the Ferrari.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: You know, Dean, I can't help wondering whether it'll ever get that good for me.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Anderson, the only difference between you and that greaseball, is that he has a license and you don't. In two days we open a whole new chapter. (motioning to his handle bars) Get in. I'll drive you home. Les looks at Dean's BEAT TO SHIT death trap bike.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Unh, unh. Too much is at stake. They'll never let me take my driver's exam in traction.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Les, your license is as important to me as it is to you. I'll take it easy. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White knuckles. Les hangs on as a sadistic Dean speeds al the sidewalk. About to collide with a JOGGER, Dean cuts onto:

dialogues.speaker: THE STREET
dialogues.text: zigzagging in and out of TRAFFIC. A HONK here, a honk the Dean JOLTS the bike back up on the SIDEWALK. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les tries to absorb the shock. Dean laughs, pedals faster He whips Les through:

dialogues.speaker: LOW HANGING BRANCHES
dialogues.text: They flap against Les' face. Dean's having a riot. Les wants to start one. The torturous branches give way to:

dialogues.speaker: A FEROCIOUS DOG CHAINED ON A PORCH
dialogues.text: Dean has the bike headed straight for it. Its mouth salivates. As Dean swerves Les by it, the dog runs and pu his chain taut, swinging out against an imaginary wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: making sure to run Les through a SPRINKLER. This is Les' house; large and colonial, its landscaping perfectly groo Ahead of them, in front of the garage, there's an Audi 50 Turbo. It's surrounded by mounds of dusty boxes and garag junk. Dean slaloms through it.

dialogues.speaker: DEVILLE
dialogues.text: sits parked at an angle, barely squeezing in. Sky blue. Gleaming chrome. It's in mint condition. Dean and Les rid in. Dean jams on the brakes. Les slides painfully off the handlebars. He gives Dean a dirty look. END OF CREDITS.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Just a painful reminder of what you're leaving behind. (beat) Whose Caddie?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: My grandfather's. Can you believe it's sixteen years old? It only has twenty thousand miles on it. Dean gets off his bike and lets it crash to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (examining it) It's intense. What's it doing here? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: He's afraid to take it on long trips so he borrowed my dad's car for a week.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (opening the door) I gotta tell you, Les, this boat would kick-ass up at Archie’s. Do you think we can get it for Saturday night?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (o.s8.) Not a chance in hell, Dean. They turn. It's Les' DAD -- good-looking, early forties, wears grimy work clothes. He walks into the garage, remov Dean's hand from the door, and buffs the chrome.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: You have a better chance of winning the Nobel Prize for physics than you do of getting in this car. Les looks at Dean as if to say "Does that answer your question?"

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Hi Dad.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (to the boys) How ‘bout a hand helping me move this junk?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (picking up his bike) I'd really love to, Mr. Anderson, (a fake cough) but I'm sort of allergic to dust and cardboard boxes. He coughs again. Dad doesn't even bother. Dean gets on hi bike.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (driving off) See you tonight. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Dad? Do you think you could tell me for sure if I can use Mom's car Saturday night?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (shoving a dusty box at him) Do me a favor, will ya, Les? Just pass your driver's exam. And then we'll talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, Les, Natalie and Rudy sit at the table. Rudy is the cute, ten year old brother you can only find in the movie As they munch away at their dinner, one by one they look in awe...

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Looking more like nine years pregnant, rather than nine months, she carries the most humongous plate of mashed potatoes, spotted with mini-pickles, chocolate chips and potato chips. Instead of putting it in the center of the table, she plops it down in front of her table setting. With the family still looking on disgustedly, she picks u the ketchup bottle, and starts squirting it out on her fo (HAPPY FACE)...

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: For your information, this is exactly what I ate when I was pregnant with all of you. She downs her first bite. It scares them back to their meals.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Unh, unh.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Did you get a chance to look at those brochures? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (pulling a crumpled brochure from his back pocket) Sure did.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Well? What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (flipping through it) A twenty-three thousand dollar BMW for a sixteen year old kid who's never had a job in his life? I think it's a great idea. Les is humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Les, you only completed your driver's ed course two hours ago. You don't even have a license yet.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: But Dad, it wouldn't be just for me. It would be for Natalie too.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Don't include me in your obsession.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Miss Mature. Is there anything wrong with being American?

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: A BMW at sixteen? It's more like spoiled. Karl says... Everyone stops what they're doing ala E. F. Hutton.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Can you people please be serious for once in your life? (beat) Karl says that in America the people are misled to believe that a car represents freedom and individuality, when, in essence, it is more oppressive than anything else, burdening the individual with materialistic costs, such as insurance, gas and repairs. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Who cares what your Commie boyfriend thinks? I think we'd all prefer to be burdened with the cost of an automobile, than with bread lines and two year waiting lists for a washing machine.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I agree. Mother starts to boil.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: You two are so simple, it's frightening.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Why are you even getting your license?

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: (upset and getting up from the table) I'm not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Natalie, if you prefer to eat standing up, that's fine with me. But nobody leaves the table until we finish eating.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: This is the most oppressive environment a child could be subjected to. Natalie sits down. We hear a loud HONK-HONK! Les stands u

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (wiping his mouth) That's for me.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: You heard me Les. Whoever it is will have to wait a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (still standing) But, Maaa. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Les? Do you want to use my car Saturday night? Les sits down like he's playing musical chairs! The famil eats in silence. We hear another HONK, and then a couple quick HONKS, and then a HONNNKKK... The family tries to ignore it, but it's more than annoying. It starts again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanging over, from the back to the front seat, leaning on horn is Dean. Dean's MOM and his LITTLE SISTER ride in front. They're used to this behavior.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: The obnoxious HONKING continues. Everyone except Les has stopped eating. Cheery, he munches away as if nothing is going on. Mom and Dad boil. Dad has had it.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Les, if you're not out of this house in five seconds, there's a good chance you'll never drive anything but a golf ball. A victorious Les calmly excuses himself from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now this is a party. Loud music. Sixteen-year-old kids al over the place. ALL THE GORGEOUS GIRLS AND GUYS huddle around expensive SLICK DRIVING MACHINES, and competing ca stereos. If you happen to be a male without a car, you ma as well be at home with a Playboy. The Datsun makes its way down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An uncomfortable backseat, filled with junk. Les and Dean sit squished together, practically eating their knees. Th front seat is pushed all the way back. Dean's little munchkin sister sits comfortably in the passenger seat. They approach the party. Dean's mom slows down. Embarrass Dean and Les duck. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DEAN'S MOM
dialogues.text: Is there something wrong with the car, Dean?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: It's not the car, Ma. It's you, you're driving. Just drop us off around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dean and Les pull themselves out of the car, a GLOSSY BLACK GTO, with a confederate flag attached to its antenn slows down across the street. Inside the GTO are THREE of the scariest and rowdiest looking HIGH SCHOOL DROPOUTS yo ever seen. They're laughing at the boys being dropped off mom.

dialogues.speaker: THE DRIVER
dialogues.text: Hey boys, does Mommy drive you to the little boys' room, also? Les and Dean are crushed. As the derelicts drive away laughing, we hear their crazy horn. The Funeral March... "DUM, DUM, DaDUM... DUM, DaDUM, DaDUM, DaDUM."

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (to his mother) Sorry, I didn't introduce you, Ma. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: See you at twelve?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN'S MOM
dialogues.text: I'll be right here at eleven.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I'll call.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN'S MOM
dialogues.text: It's a school night, Dean. If you're not standing here between eleven and eleven o' two, I'm changing the locks. The Datsun drives off. Composed, they strut around the corner. Ahead of them, in front of the estate and all the kids, a HONDA pulls up. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: jumps out and WAVES GOOD-BYE TO HIS MOTHER. Older looking but by no means better looking than Les and Dean, he wear glasses and isn't ashamed of being dropped off by his mot He waves to Dean and Les. They turn into the party, ignor him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les, Dean, and Charles sip fruit punch. They sit alone on the front steps gawking at the hoards of cute girls surrounding the guys and their cars. Impressive, but sickening.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I know exactly what you're thinking, Les. I'm thinking the same thing. I'm not sure about Charles. (beat) Why am I so alone here? I'm good looking, I've got a great sense of humor, and yet there's not one single female within twenty yards of me? Can you find one of them who isn't within arms reach of a car?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: They've even monopolized the fifteen year olds.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: You guys are pathetic. Life does exist outside a V-Eight.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Not in this country, it doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: And do you know what the beauty of it all is? The beauty of it all, Les, is that Saturday afternoon, less than forty-eight hours away, the people at the DMV are going to be handing you your license... our Les' eyes glitter. He's in a trance. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: You can say good-bye to the humiliation of public transportation, and not being able to date someone who isn't conveniently close to a bus stop. You're going to be free, Les. One of them. (beat) And on Saturday night, when we pull into Archie's Atomic in your mom's Audi 5000 TURBO, all this is going to be at our fingertips. In fact, Archie's makes this place look like Sesame Street.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: To you Archie's makes the Playboy Channel look like Sesame Street.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Archie's is the joint. I swear it. My brother used to go there every weekend. He says the ratio of girls to guys is five to one. And we're not talkin' dogs, we're talkin' bunnies. The place is a paradise. (beat) I'm telling you, Les. The secret to your happiness, and ultimately our happiness, as long as we live in this country, is a driver's license.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: You can't possibly believe that bullshit, can you?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (leoking around at all the cars, girls and happiness) Charles. Seeing is believing. You gotta believe him.  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft lighting. Kids sitting, standing, talking, necking. Les, Dean, and Charles slump by the punch bowl observing decadence.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Do you ever wonder what kind of car would be most appropriate for some of these wenches to lose their virginity in?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: You never cease to amaze me, Deano.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Seriously. Look at Cheryl Lieberman.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL LIEBERMAN
dialogues.text: A sixteen-year-old JAP. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: A Camaro.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Cheryl Lieberman? A Trans Am.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Beth Maclaine.

dialogues.speaker: BETH MACLAINE
dialogues.text: Pristine. Conservative Anglo Saxon.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: A Volvo. Maybe a station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Bonnie Dupa.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE DUPA
dialogues.text: We CAN ONLY SEE her face as someone is sitting in front o her. She's sleaze to the max.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: (o.8.) A van. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Nah, a Harley.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (o.8.; reverent tone) Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN AND CHARLES
dialogues.text: (0.8.3; shocked) A Mercedes?

dialogues.speaker: THE BOYS
dialogues.text: They turn to Les only to see him gaping, mouth open. Dean and Charles look up and become entranced, as well.

dialogues.speaker: A VISION
dialogues.text: Standing, framed, in the doorway, backlit, the light shin through her dress, exposing the silhouette of her long le At seventeen she looks twenty. She's an untouchable.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (still reverent) Mercedes Lane.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: What more can be said?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: I've bumped into her a million times, and she's never once bumped into me. Mercedes heads for them, arguing with her older looking boyfriend, PAOLO. He looks very out of place.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: You don't own me, I can do whatever I like. Women have rights in this country. Not like Chile or Argentina, where they worship their men. They barge through the boys as if they were a string of beads. Les "quivers" beside Mercedes as she pours herself some punch. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PAOLO
dialogues.text: It has nothing to do with worship, it has to do with going to parties with... with kids.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: I happen to go to school with these kids. I have friends here.

dialogues.speaker: PAOLO
dialogues.text: Friends? These children can do nothing for you.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: (cold) Can we just stop this discussion? There are some things you and I will never agree on.

dialogues.speaker: PAOLO
dialogues.text: (flustered) Mercedes. I'm beginning to perspire. You know I hate to perspire. (turning to go) Are you coming?

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: I think I can find my own way home, thank you. He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: And Paolo? If you're wondering about Saturday night, I just remembered...

dialogues.speaker: PAOLO
dialogues.text: (turning back) Don't do this to me, Mercedes. You'll regret it.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: I've made other plans. I already have a date.

dialogues.speaker: PAOLO
dialogues.text: With who?

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: With him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mercedes turns to a shocked Les.

dialogues.speaker: PAOLO
dialogues.text: Him?

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: (to Les) Didn't we make arrangements?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (hesitant) I... I believe so. But, nothing was final.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Well now they're final.

dialogues.speaker: PAOLO
dialogues.text: You'll pay for this, Mercedes. Paolo storms away. Les watches, afraid to speak. Mercedes downs her punch. She fills her glass again, and downs it. Les who? WE PUSH IN ON Les. He's in a daze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids pile out of class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean and Charles get on the bus. Les stands on the curb. The bus starts its engine. Fancy cars pull away.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I cannot believe you, Les. You're blowing the greatest night of your life for a girl who probably doesn't even know you have a pulse.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Dean, believe it!

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (betrayed) That's pathetic. After all these years we finally get a chance to go to Archie's, and now you're telling me it's off? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: If Mercedes pulls through, you bet.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Why don't you just ask her, to make sure?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: I'd love to Charles, but I can't talk to something I can't see. Last night was the closest any of us have ever been to her.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Well you're in luck, loverboy, ‘cause she's sittin' down right behind you. Dean backs away. The bus doors slam closed in Les' face. turns around: Mercedes sits on a bench about twenty-five feet away, rea an ELLE magazine, sipping some apple juice. Les turns back to the bus. It's pulling away.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (leaning out) Go on, ask her. If you're lucky, she'll bite. Les turns back to Mercedes. She's more beautiful than ever. He walks towards her. Her blonde hair flutters in the wind. He stands beside her. Some apple juice dribbles off her bottom lip. She tongues her lips dry. It's the sexiest thing he's ever seen. He can't even talk. She glances up. Not recognizing him, she goes back to her Magazine. We hear a LOUD HONK! HONK! !!!! It scares Mercedes. Les turns, shocked to see his father in the Cadillac, pul up in front of them. He HONKS again. It's the loudest hor in the world. Les, embarrassed, ignores his father.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (rolling down the window) Les? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The height of embarrassment. Les coolly walks by Mercedes Then, instead of getting into the car, he walks in front it, across the street. Dad rolls down the window, HONKING again.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Les. It's me, your father. Cringe. He tries to get out of her sight. Mercedes doesn' even notice. Dad follows beside him, like the secret service.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: What's going on, here, Les? Don't you recognize me? Still no answer. He turns the corner. So does Dad. Finally, out of her sight, Les gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WHITE INTERIOR, impeccably clean. The immensity of the dwarfs Les. We SEE BAGS OF PAMPERS in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Is there something wrong with having a father, these days?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Dad, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: I ran some errands for your mom, and I thought I'd come by and take you driving. I figured if you could handle this cruiser you could handle anything.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: But what about Grandpa?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Don't worry about Grandpa. Who knows what he's doing with my car?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (excited) Okay. Dad slides over. Les climbs into the driver's seat, movin it way up close. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He checks his mirrors then takes a deep breath. He puts h flicker on, then pulls out, very slowly... cautiously. Immediately, the car screeches to a halt fifteen feet bef a stop sign. Dad rubs his neck.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Sorry. The brakes are a little sensitive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les smoothly turns the Cadillac off a busy street into a residential neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les, driving for a while now, begins to get the hang of i He stops smoothly at a stop sign. Suddenly, he stares wid eyed, frozen.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: That's a long enough stop. Make a right here.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Up the block, Les sees Mercedes Lane.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: I have to ask you a favor. You can say no, but I'll never ask you another one as long as I live.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Les, you know that's a lie.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: You see that girl up ahead? Her name is Mercedes Lane. To put it simply, if she asked me to marry her tomorrow, I'd definitely say yes. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (excited) So. Let's drive by her.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Dad, she just asked me out last night. If I drive by with you in the car, she'll never look at me again. Even if I were standing on her chest.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: You're asking me to let you drive this car, alone? Without a license? Are you insane?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: I'll just drive by, say hello and circle back. It'll take two minutes. Dad, sizing up the situation, looks at Les, then at Merce who walks farther up the block.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (earnestly) I just want to see if she was serious.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (with a big heart) Sure.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: And Dad... (looking at groceries) Would you mind? What can Dad say? He gets out, with the Pampers, then watches Les pull away.

dialogues.speaker: APPROACHING MERCEDES
dialogues.text: He rolls down the window and honks. She turns, gives hima dirty look, and keeps walking. He shadows her.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Mercedes? She stops and looks inside, puzzled. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Les Anderson, from the party last night.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Oh, you scared me. I didn't recognize you. Some jerk honked at me a little while ago in a car just like this.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: You live around here, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Unh, unh. Just up the street.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Hop in, I'll give you a lift?

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Sure, that'd be fun. As she's about to open the front door:

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Wait a second. Les jumps out of the car, runs around the passenger side, insists she get in the back seat. Charmed, she does.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: down the road, shakes his head in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adjusting the rearview mirror, Les momentarily holds on h chest, then up to her face. He smiles. He sees Dad, in th mirror, holding the bags.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Which house is yours?

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: It's right down the block. He drives up half a block. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (about to pull into the driveway) Okaaayyy-

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: But... I'm not going home.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (stunned) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Into Cedarbrook, to a friend's place. You don't mind, do you? Les is stunned, caught completely off guard. He looks at his:

dialogues.speaker: REARVIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: His father, still holding the bags, stands alone.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (weakly) No, not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, with the bags beside him on the sidewalk, is livid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercedes walks away from the Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (calling out) Mercedes?

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: (coming back) Unh, unh. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (courageous) Last night at the party, you mentioned something about you and I going out Saturday night. I was just curious... Are we still on? She doesn't have the heart.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Sure... Call me, tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (pulling out a pen) Great, let me give you my number in case something comes up. You never know.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: (handing him her Elle Magazine) Here, write it on this. He excitedly writes his number on the front cover, then h it back to her.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Thanks again for the lift, Les.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les coasts down the street like a cop on surveillance. Suddenly, he spots Dad a block ahead, carrying the huge grocery bags. His jacket is off and his shirt is soaked i sweat. As Les pulls up, Dad glares at him. If looks could kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les sits stiffly, in a chair. Dad disheveled, his shirt soaked with sweat, circles Les like a shark.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (angry) How could you do it, Les? (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DAD (cont'd) You gave me your word and you used up your last favor? Do you realize where this leaves you?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Not in good shape, but just let me explain. I admit I should never have let her in the car, but she lived three houses down. I thought I was taking her home. (leoking at Mom) Mom, I'm sure there were many similar romantic gestures when Dad was dating you. Mom lies on her side in the den wearing a workout outfit, doing scissor-kick exercises, to a pregnancy video. If Mo Dick were a pregnant woman living in America, she'd look this.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: (thinking) I don't know. There must have been. We're married. Mom smiles. Dad looks at her as if to say, "Thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Why didn't you just tell her the truth?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Tell Mercedes Lane I don't have a license? And risk her having a heart attack from laughing so hard? Put yourself in my shoes. Dad looks at Les. Then to Mom for help. Forget it, Dad, you're on your own.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (giving in) Well, consider yourself lucky that I didn't have a heart attack walking home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stereo, TV, CD, boyhood Americana. Posters of cars cover walls. We faintly hear classical music seeping through th walls. The boys are over. While Les cuts Mercedes' pictur out of the high school yearbook, Dean gives him a hard ti (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Do you know what happens if you get caught driving without a license? They make you wait two years before you can take the test again. Two years, Les. Twenty-four months. That's a lot of bus rides.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Relax, I didn't get caught. (pinning the picture over his desk) And you'd do the same. (beat) Now did you guys come over to ask me some questions? Because if you didn't, then I have some studying to do. A tense silence. Les hands Charles the Driver's Ed book. Through the walls, the classical music builds in intensit

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: All right. How can you identify a blind pedestrian to whom you must yield the right of way?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: You're not serious.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: By their white cane, or guard dog.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: This is a complete waste of time. You know your stuff, Les. You've been a passenger in a car for sixteen years. It's not like you're from Bedrock or something. You've lived and breathed this theory bullshit. The music booms through the walls, building to a crescend

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (disturbed by the music) What is that shit?  29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tchaikovsky!!! Bookish Natalie sits at her desk studying Driver's Ed manual, taking notes, trying to memorize. As studies, her body responds to the music with great intens And then relaxes when the music becomes quiet... Suddenly from an INTERCOM above her desk, we hear Dean's obnoxious voice.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (voice over) Hey, Naaaatalie! If you were ina car traveling at the speed of fifty- five miles per hour, and you collided with a runaway train, would that create any improvements in your face? Her pencil snaps. A total disruption of concentration. Silence. And now we hear the loudest and most disgusting BURP of all time. And then wails of laughter... And then Dean, again.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (voice over) Good luck on your exam tomorrow, Einstein!

dialogues.speaker: INT. D.M.V. TESTING ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: A SEA OF APPLICANTS, mostly kids, some older. They sit in front of their computer screens and keyboards, ready to begin. Les and Natalie sit beside each other. MISS HELLMA an older BLUE-HAIRED WOMAN stands at the front of the roo

dialogues.speaker: MISS HELLMAN
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, children. In the next fifteen minutes you will be given thirty questions. Any more than five mistakes will be considered a failing grade. We'll begin at the sound of the bell. She looks up at the clock, a second away from one o'clock The bell RINGS. The students begin. Les is off: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Question #1. What should you do if you miss your exit fro an expressway? A-Jam on the breaks and back up. B-Make a quick U-turn. C-Go on to the next one.

dialogues.speaker: LES CHUCKLES TO HIMSELF
dialogues.text: He taps C. Correct. One for one. Question #2. The screen shows a stretch of freeway with three lanes, marked A, B, C. (C being the right lane) "Which is usually the smoothest lane of traffic? A, B, or c."

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (to himself) Why don't they just give licenses away? He presses C. WRONG.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (shocked) What? He looks over at Natalie. She's just tapping away and smiling. He looks back at his screen. The next question. He looks at it and looks at it. He decides. He winces. Wrong again. Beads of sweat begin to gather on his forehe AROUND THE ROOM - NERVOUS STUDENTS' HANDS. 1. A GIRL'S bangled hand plays with her hair. 2. A GUY nervously bites his nails. 3. A GIRL'S jappy fingernails clack away on the desk. 4. A DUMB JOCK cracks his knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: scratches his scalp, and taps his foot nervously. He look around, takes a deep breath, presses a key, then waits fo response. A sigh of relief. Natalie cooks.

dialogues.speaker: HER SCREEN
dialogues.text: Question number 24. What actions should you take if anoth vehicle passes you on the left? A-Speed up and don't let in. B-Take down his license number. C-Slow down. She presses C. Correct. 24 for 24. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LES AND NATALIE
dialogues.text: A picture of opposites. Natalie, effervescent, full of li Les, a wreck. We see in his face that it's coming down to the wire.

dialogues.speaker: LES'S SCREEN
dialogues.text: It reads: WARNING!!! ONE MORE INCORRECT ANSWER AND YOU

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: (o.8.) Finished. Natalie bounces past him. She's all smiles. He hates her.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Question number 26. At 55 m.p.h. you come upon a large puddle of water. Do you A-pump your brakes. B-gently ease your foot off the gas pedal. C-Accelerate. Les' finger go from A to B and then to the side. He pauses toiling. He presses A. WRONG! You have failed. His hands begin to shake. His eyes freeze on the screen. It's the end of the world. Out of frustration he:

dialogues.speaker: WHACKS THE COMPUTER
dialogues.text: with both hands on either side. The screen blips off and stays off. He looks up and around. All the students in hi row have their hands up. What has he done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les, nervously, waits at a counter with a crowd of people Miss Hellman returns.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HELLMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Anderson, you'll have to thank your sister for this one.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MISS HELLMAN
dialogues.text: At the present moment, the Department of Motor Vehicles' computers are down, so we can't get your test results. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MISS HELLMAN (cont'd) However, considering your sister received a perfect score, we're going to pass you, and allow you to take your road test. (beat) How different can you and your twin sister actually be? Les smiles. His lips crack, he's so happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheery and full of life, Les opens the door and peers in.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CAR
dialogues.text: sits MR. KELLY. Hair slicked back, wearing dark aviator sunglasses, he's the-sickest, most maligned, frightening- lecking human being you've ever seen. Les' stomach drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stick shift. A typical road test car. A little nervous, she doesn't seem to have the grit she usually has. She's having trouble adjusting her seatbelt. MR. NICE GUY, her back driving instructor, observes and looks over his checklist.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NICE GUY
dialogues.text: Let me help you with that.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: I think I can get it. She struggles. He leans over, mashing his body up against hers, fixing the belt and holding it for a few Mississipp too long.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NICE GUY
dialogues.text: There's nothing to be nervous about, Natalie. You'll have your license before you know it. Take your time. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE LES' CAR
dialogues.text: Les, anxious to roll, listens to some last minute warning from Mr. Kelly. A full steaming cup of coffee sits on the dash.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KELLY
dialogues.text: Anderson. I want you to take a long hard look at that cup of coffee. Now I love my coffee. It may be the only thing I truly cherish on this god forsaken mudball we call earth. What I'm trying to say is that most inspectors use a checklist. (holding up the clipboard) I don't believe in them. (he throws it out the window) What I do believe in, is my cup of coffee. You see, that coffee is hot, filled right to the brim. If it spills on me it'll probably burn me. And no one likes to get burned. So, if you burn me, you fail. If you don't, you pass. It's as simple as that. (beat) Whenever you're ready.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE NATALIE'S CAR
dialogues.text: Natalie puts her flicker on, checks her blind spot, then pulls out in first gear. A very ROCKY, JERKY, start.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NICE GUY
dialogues.text: No need to apologize, it happens to everyone.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE LES' CAR
dialogues.text: He gently slips the car into gear, balancing the clutch a the gas like James Bond diffusing a bomb. He perspires. O eye on the road the other on the cup. As he pulls away:

dialogues.speaker: THE COFFEE
dialogues.text: swishes, just barely hitting the rim. He's made it. Kelly takes a sip, and then puts it back.  34. EXT. D.M.V. WE CRANE UP ABOVE THE LOT as Les' car follows Natalie's c out of the lot.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KELLY
dialogues.text: (o.s., drill sergeant) Make a left at the intersection, Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NICE GUY
dialogues.text: (o.s., imitating the Pope) Natalie, can you please make a right at the corner. Les' car, cutting across traffic, makes a left into the hectic city. Natalie's car makes a right into quiet suburbia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie's car runs smoothly down a residential street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les' car is in the thick of Saturday morning traffic. An AMBULANCE is behind them, siren wailing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ritzy quiet neighborhood. The car is set on a small hil more like a bump. Inside the car, an air of tranquility.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NICE GUY
dialogues.text: Let's see how you can handle the clutch on a hill. It's a joke. Smoother than smooth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In traffic, at the top of what most skiers consider the P An ANTIQUE CAR pulls within three inches of his back bump (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Les checks his rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: THE ANTIQUE CAR
dialogues.text: practically in his trunk. The coffee angles against the c a hair away from the rim. The light turns green. The guy HONKS. The coffee vibrates Droplets of sweat appear on his forehead. He releases the clutch and smocthly pulls away. The cup is fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a moving car in sight. Birds chirp. All is well.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NICE GUY
dialogues.text: Stop just up ahead of this car on the right. I 'd like you to parallel park. Natalie stops, signals right, then shifts into reverse. T spot is big enough to park a 747. She handles it easily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les, stopped, has his right flicker on. Traffic backs up behind him. He's to parallel park in a spot a stroller wo have trouble fitting in. He does a textbook parking job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie. Her typical sour expression. The flash pops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie, at a bureau counter, waits for her license.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Congratulations. Drive safely.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Thank you.  36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie walks through the parking lot on her way home. We SEE Les, across the street, his left flicker on, waiting a gap in the traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Natalie walks out of the parking lot, on her way home, pulls in. We FOLLOW Les' car as he's about to park.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. LES' CAR
dialogues.text: The coffee cup balances on the dash. Les is home free. BU SUDDENLY, A GIRL runs out in front of the car waving her license at a friend.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I got it. I got it. Les JAMS ON THE BRAKES to avoid hitting her. THE CUP ON THE DASH FLIES INTO KELLY'S LAP. Les looks at Kelly, pleading, afraid. Kelly calmly picks the cup up th turns it over.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KELLY
dialogues.text: You're in luck, Anderson. The cup was empty. See you on the battlefield sometime. Les, grateful, would love to hug Mr. Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON LES, a million dollar smile. The camera flashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les, exploding with anticipation, waits in line to pick u his license. The Attendant signals him. He looks at it: The Holy Grail, The Ark of The Covenant. can't walk. As he's about to step away, the attendant sto him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: (looking at a list) Mr. Anderson. Hold on, one second. Someone wants to speak with you. Holding his license, he watches as the attendant, with li walks over to Miss Hellman. His heart skips a beat. Large beads of perspiration. Miss Hellman walks toward hi BOOM-BOOM, BOOM-BOOM, goes his heart. His future passes before him. We hear voices in DEEP REVERB.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (voice over) Just pass your driver's exam, and then we'll talk.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: (voice over) Sure. Call me

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: (voice over) Life does exist outside a V-8.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (voice over) You're going to be free, Les. One of them... one of them... one of them.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HELLMAN
dialogues.text: Well, well, Mr. Anderson. Mr. Anderson. Les snaps out of it.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (squeaking) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MISS HELLMAN AND HER VICIOUS SMILE
dialogues.text: His eyes begin to water.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HELLMAN
dialogues.text: We were able to retrieve your test results from the computer, Mr. Anderson. And, as I suppose you already know, you failed. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MISS HELLMAN (cont'd) (handing him his test results with one hand) God giveth... (taking the license with the other) «--and God taketh away. Don't mess with the Department of Motor Vehicles! As she rips up his license, the IMAGE BLURS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devastated. Walking sluggishly, staring at his failed exa It's the end of the world. He crams the test in back pock The edge of it sticks out. A convertible VW Rabbit whips by, music blaring. Sixteen year old girls and guys rock to the music. Probably the happiest day of their lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les enters. The house is quiet. There's no one home. Head down, he treks upstairs to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: deeply depressed, walks into his room. His door is plaste with telephone messages, all from Charles and Dean; "Pick up." "Congratulations, you made it." ...Deeper depression On his desk, a GIFT WRAPPED BOX. There's a card on top. I reads, "Good Driving. Love, Mom and Dad." He tears the wrapping off and looks in. He pulls out a CHAUFFEUR'S CAP Even deeper depression. Dazed, he stares at Mercedes’ picture. She never looked better. He never looked worse. We hear someone come into the house.

dialogues.speaker: MOM AND DAD
dialogues.text: (o.8.) Hellooocccoo. Helloocoooocce... We're home. Horror. He has to face his parents.  39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A newly decorated baby room. Moby Mom and Dad remove a CR from a box. Les slouched over, walks in.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Hey, sport. What's the good news?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (dejected) Mom, Dad, I have something to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (playing) You already dented the car.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: What is it? Mom and Dad look at him, eagerly. Les looks them in the e What's he gonna do??? Could this be it??? Suddenly, his frown becomes the biggest smile. He locks genuinely excited. He starts to sing and dance around the room.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (to the tune of Soul Man) I'm a free man. Dodo, dodo, dodo, dodo. I'ma free man, yaaahhh.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Thank youuuuuuuuu...

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Was it a breeze?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Like taking candy from a baby.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (laughing) I filled mom's car up this afternoon, if you feel like taking it for a drive. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (stopped in his tracks) No thanks, Dad. I think I'm gonna go to my room and lie down. I'm exhausted. Mom and Dad are puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Is there something wrong, Les?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Wrong? Are you kidding me? This is the greatest day of my life. Sixteen-years-old with a license in my wallet. I couldn't ask for more.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: So why don't you want to take the car for a drive and celebrate a little, get it out of your system?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: I don't know if you guys remember... sixteen years of waiting and dreaming is a lot of pressure. It's a very powerful moment, and I'm not sure sitting behind the wheel is the place for me to be right now.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Can we at least see your license?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Mom, the picture is so ugly, I'm even afraid to look at it. It smells.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: We're your parents, Les. We changed your diapers, remember? I'm quite sure we could handle it.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (leaving the room) Sorry, Dad. It's worse than dirty diapers. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (to Mom) How can anything be worse than dirty diapers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les realizes what he just backed himself into, and he kin likes it. Rudy comes barging in the front door, excited a hell, looking for his brother. Les is in full stride... Rudy runs to him and slaps him "high five."

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Awwrighhhhht. (beat) When can we go for a drive?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Later, later. Let me just make a few phone calls. Rudy buys it, another one sold. The phone rings. Les pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les dances in, whistling, he's a new man. He opens his ph book and turns to the name "Mercedes," beside a Mercedes symbol. He dials the number and waits... it's BUSY. Just he puts it down, it RINGS. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiny. Water pipes abound. A pigsty a pig wouldn't live in Dean holds the telephone up to the speaker. Charles hits play on the tape deck and suddenly the sounds of A ROCK CONCERT CROWD CHEERING AND SCREAMING blasts out of the speakers. Intercut Les and Dean. Les listens... He loves it. It finally fades out.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: You're the king, Les. You did it, man. How does it feel?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Deano baby! Hang on a second, I'm looking for my keys. Wait! (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LES (cont'd) Here they are. Right beside my AAA card. They laugh. Another one sold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les is in seventh heaven, singing and whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom flicks on the washer, then leaves the room with an em laundry basket balancing on her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom pokes her head in, while Les is still in the shower. grabs his dirty underwear, socks and jeans. As she plops them into her basket, we SEE the corner of Les' test resu edging out of his back pocket. Les turns the shower off. Dad pops his head into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: I wanna see you in the den in a few minutes, chief.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (on top of the world) I'm there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing by the washer Mom empties everyone's pockets; Da Rudy's, Les' jeans... Without realizing what it is, she places Les' failed exam on the counter. As it sits there partially unfolds. Mom loads the washer. INT. DEN —- NIGHT Dad sits with Natalie, waiting for Les. Behind Dad, Rudy sits in front of a GIANT SCREEN TV, with the sound off. H watching "THE FRENCH CONNECTION."

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (frustrated) Where's Les?  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing a bathrobe, he's on the phone. Still busy. Confused, he leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outfits scattered about. Mercedes is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (voice over) Mercedes, you could have any guy you'd like. Forget Paolo. He's old enough to be your mother's younger brother.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: But why hasn't he called? He's going to the club tonight, I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les, full of life, sits beside Natalie. As Dad talks, the famous chase scene from "THE FRENCH CONNECTION" unfolds.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: With Mom expecting any day now, it's extremely important that there is always one car at home. I cannot make that any clearer. Am I understood?

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: (sour) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Absolutely, hundred percent. Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Les... We don't want Mom going into labor without a car here to drive her to the hospital. Taxis are unreliable, and you both know how slow buses can be. If I'm out, one of you must be here. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DAD (cont'd) The same goes for me when the both of you are out. The overriding consideration now is your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mom sorts the laundry, she watches TV: A "Pregnancy Period" home video guide. A WOMAN speaks. Beside Mom, resting on top of Les' still partially-folded test, is a of PICKLED PIG'S FEET with CHOCOLATE SYRUP on it.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (on TV) ++eas long as you aren't experiencing any dizzy spells, and as long as you can still fit behind the wheel, you can safely drive short distances up to delivery day. Don't, however, try to drive yourself to the hospital while in labor.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DEN NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dad continues. In the chase scene, behind him, Popeye Doy swerves away, avoiding a baby in a stroller.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Now, I've put together a list of the rules of the road that I think we should go over. Dad pulls out some NOTES and hands a copy to Les and Nata

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Dad...

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: This way you'll never be able to say you don't remember hearing them. Take a minute to look them over. They may end up saving your life. They flip through them. They can't believe it. INT. LES' ROOM — NIGHT Les walks into his room and without giving it a thought pitches Dad's rules and regulations into the garbage can.  45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While gathering everyone's loose change and pocket conten Mom notices Les' test results. She unfolds the test sheet It's obvious he failed!

dialogues.speaker: A TAPE DECK
dialogues.text: Rock and roll. A tape records. Needles bounce. "MERCEDES FAST" is scrawled on the label. PULL BACK... We SEE Rudy wearing the chauffeur's cap, standing by the rockin' ster Les dials the phone. It's ringing, finally. He signals Ru to turn it down. Silence. Joy on Les' face.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: (voice over; sexy) Hello... Suddenlytittttrriritt

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR BURSTS OPEN
dialogues.text: The boys look up. It's Dad, carrying a BOTTLE OF CHAMPAGN and TWO GLASSES. Les, receiver in hand, is stunned. He can't talk with his Dad in the room. As he hangs up the phone, WE HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Paolo? Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Rudy. Go downstairs. Les, my boy, we're drinking a toast to you. Rudy exits.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Dad, that's very thoughtful of you, but you know I shouldn't be drinking and driving.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (popping open the bottle) Les. You just saved me $26,000.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: How did I do that? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (pouring him a glass) First raise your glass. (toasting) To saving me 26,000 buckaroonies.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (taking a sip) I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Twenty-three thousand for the BMW, and three thousand for the insurance.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (excited) How did I do that? Dad whips out the test.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: With this. Les is shattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom has just told Rudy and Natalie about Les.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY AND NATALIE
dialogues.text: He failed?iiitit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les sits on his bed, head down. Dad kneels in front of hi

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Les, did it ever occur to you that you could've told your mom and me. We're your parents, not the police.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (ashamed) I just figured that I could get through the weekend and take the test over Monday.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: I know what you figured... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Les looks out into nowhere land.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Come on, Les. It's not the end of the world.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: It feels like it.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (putting his arm around Les) You'll recover. The great ones always do. The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom opens the door. It's KARL, Natalie's boyfriend. Worke of the world unite!!! He wears HORN-RIMMED GLASSES.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mrs. Anderson. Is Natascha home?

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: She'll be down in a second.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Fine, Karl. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: I admire you for having the courage to bring a child into this oppressive world.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: (calling for help) NATALIEEEEE...

dialogues.speaker: INT. LES' ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: On his bed, staring at the ceiling. PAN TO the clock OVER his bed. It reads 8:50.  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulling out of the Anderson driveway. It huffs and it puf and it BACKFIRES. It sounds like shit!!

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Are you sure you don't want to take my mother's Audi? This car's never going to make it to the rally.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: (proud) Natascha, don't let this old warrior's heartbeat deceive you. It has more than a lifetime worth of travel left in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercedes lies on the floor, beside the phone, with her fe up on a chair. She looks sad and very alone. She rolls ov and grabs the ELLE magazine off of her bed. Leafing throu it, something on the front cover catches her eye... Les' number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN BACK TO Les in the same position. He hasn't moved. Th phone rings, and rings, and rings. He picks it up. Interc

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (picking it up) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Is Les Anderson in, please?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (confused) This is Les.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Les? This is Mercedes Lane. Do you remember me? This can't be. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (trying to be cool) Remember you?... Ah... I'm not sure. Of course, Mercedes. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: A little lonely, actually. Les' eyes pop out. He cringes

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: I thought we had a date this evening. I figured I'd call you, since you hadn't called yet.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Actually, I just got in. I was out... deep sea fishing all day. at the sound of his feeble lie.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: You haven't changed your mind about tonight, have you?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Tonight? Now? No.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: So you can pick me up in twenty minutes? (no response) He looks at the clock and sees the time.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Hang on. Les puts the phone down and looks out his window at Mom’s

dialogues.speaker: AUDI 5000
dialogues.text: parked in the driveway. He bolts out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les gently opens their door and peers in. The TV is on. M and Dad are asleep. The keys to the Audi are on the night table beside Dad. He closes the door and takes a deep breath. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (to himself) An innocent girl, a harmless drive. What could possibly go wrong?

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN HIS ROOM
dialogues.text: He slides in and picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (with confidence) Mercedes? I'll be there in half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Great. And Les?... Can you bring some liquor?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (unbelieving) Liquor? You mean alcohol? A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Les?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Unh, unh.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Vodka makes me crazy. He must be dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: tiptoes to Dad's night table. Les reaches for the keys, b just as he's about to snatch them, Dad rolls over, stretc out, plopping his hand down on top of them. It's no use. Les walks out, turning the TV up even louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les searches the drawers of a desk. He pulls out a box of spare keys... nothing. He checks other drawers... nothing He doesn't know what to do... or does he?  51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les walks-in and takes a long hard look at the Cadillac. It's radiant. He looks in and sees the keys in the igniti

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (to himself) Anderson, you should be castrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A locked liquor cabinet. Les feels around back and pulls a SMALL MAGNETIC TIN BOX. A HIDE-A-KEY. He opens the cabinet and pulls out a full bottle of vodka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les walks into the garage, carrying a cooler and a flask. lays them down beside the trunk. As he opens the car door the CAR ALARM sounds. It's LOUD AS HELL! He lunges into t car and turns it off. He listens for his parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're still asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garage door inches up.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CAR
dialogues.text: He turns the ignition part way, unlocking the steering, t shifts the car into neutral. The car doesn't budge. He gets out of the car and begins to push it. It starts to... ROLL SLOWLY, then pick up speed. He shuffles alongside, trying to open the door. It rolls onto the FRO LAWN, headed straight for the SIX-FOOT-HIGH PERFECTLY- MANICURED FRONT HEDGES. Les holds his breath as the Cadillac plows through Picass hedges, onto the street, thumping to a stop against the c Les can't believe his eyes: the seven foot gap in the hed and tire tracks in the lawn. As best he can, he props the bushes up, and stomps on the tire tracks. He runs to: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: THE GARAGE
dialogues.text: where he unscrews the light bulbs and hits the automatic control. He runs back to the Caddie. As he pulls away in one direction:

dialogues.speaker: THE CITROEN
dialogues.text: on its last leg, pulls into THE DRIVEWAY from the other.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: If you're not convinced this car's about to die, maybe we should wait until it catches fire and cremates itself.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Need you be so cruel, Natascha.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: (rolling her eyes) Let me just get the keys to my mother's Audi. She walks into the house. A defeated Karl waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad and Mom are fast asleep, wrapped in covers. Natalie searches for the keys. She finally spots them under Dad's hand. Unlike Les, she picks up Dad's hand, and removes th Audi key. Dad wakes up and looks at her. She holds out the key. He smiles and falls back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMPTY! No Cadillac. We hear the Audi start up and pull away. No cars at home!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we hear the car drive away. Pregnant Mom bolts in pain grabbing her stomach. She turns on the light and waits fo the pain to subside. She's okay. She turns the light off.  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les rings and waits. Mercedes opens the door. She looks stunning.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: You look great.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Thanks, Les. You look cute. He smiles. Where's the nearest justice of the peace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les' tape is a hit. Loud. Heaven. Mercedes is having a great time.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: So where do you feel like going?

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: I know the perfect place. You'll love it. Mercedes cranks the volume even louder. As she does, a CO CAR squeezes by the Caddie giving Les a hard look. For th first time, we see in Les' face the fear of what he's abo to get himself into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A popular nightclub set in an UNSAFE NEIGHBORHOOD. The Caddie is on a line for valet parking.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CADILLAC
dialogues.text: A ton of decibels. Mercedes sips on the flask, rocking to the music. A neurotic Les watches the PARKERS manhandle t cars ahead of him. Cars fishtail, leaving a cloud of blue smoke. The VALET reaches for Les' door. Les hits the automatic l switch.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Open the door, Les. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you can't?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (pulling out) They'll destroy the gears. If I let them touch this car, they'll turn it into a manual transmission. I'll park it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An alley lined with cars with smashed windows and missing bumpers. Les backs into the only remotely safe-looking sp The Caddie lights shut off. We hear a SHRIEK. A GUNSHOT. BROKEN GLASS! The Caddie lights turn back on. The car pee out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive by the club, again, still looking, but now the on the other side of the street.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: (pointing to a spot) There's one. Les looks. It's perfect. Huge under a street lamp. He pulls in.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (noticing a parking sign) I can't park here.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: It's a tow zone.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: On a Saturday night? Les, nobody tows cars on a weekend. Look at all the cars behind us. You think they're worried? Les is. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: (Cont'd) Relax. You're acting like it's the first time you've ever driven. She struck a nerve. She gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les follows Mercedes as she approaches the LARGE CROWD of people waiting to get in. The DOORMAN recognizes Mercedes waves her in, but stops Les dead in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Hey, come on, I'm with her.

dialogues.speaker: DOORMAN
dialogues.text: (snobbish) Riiiiight. You wouldn't be with her if she were your Siamese twin. Now, run on before someone steals your tricycle, Mikie. Forget it, Les.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Mercedes realizes Les isn't with her, she spots PA To get up her nerve, Mercedes grabs some GUY's glass of champagne off the bar, and downs it. The guy looks on, confused. Mercedes is a tad flushed. This may have been h first drink. She approaches Paolo. He sees her.

dialogues.speaker: PAOLO
dialogues.text: (feigned charm) Mercedes, what a lovely surprise. Where is your high school 'throb heart? Mercedes realizes Les isn't there. A beautiful SEXY WOMAN slithers up beside Paolo, and nibbles on his ear. Mercede is repulsed.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE EL RAY'S
dialogues.text: Les, unable to weasel by the Doorman, hustles up to a win where he watches MERCEDES confront Paolo. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Behind him, at the Caddie, we see a TOW TRUCK attaching i clamps and clips to the Cadillac's frame.

dialogues.speaker: BACK INSIDE EL RAY'S FOYER
dialogues.text: Mercedes is very upset.

dialogues.speaker: PAOLO
dialogues.text: (pouring champagne) Please, Mercedes. Sit down and join us for something to drink.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: No thanks, but here's something to go with it.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: watches Mercedes wind up and slap Paolo. Les smirks, as Paolo stands stunned. INSIDE EL RAY’S Mercedes storms away. On the way out of the club, she gra the guy's MAGNUM OF CHAMPAGNE from the bucket of ice.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE EL RAY'S
dialogues.text: Les waits for Mercedes. She stomps by him, back to the ca swigging the near-full bottle of champagne. Les turns to see... THE TOW TRUCK, about to pull away with the Caddie. Blindl Les, runs across the street. Cars screech and swerve. He stands in front of the truck. The DRIVER is an overweight REDNECK covered in grease.

dialogues.speaker: REDNECK DRIVER
dialogues.text: Get out the way, boy.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (jumping on the truck's hood) You can't do this to my car.

dialogues.speaker: REDNECK DRIVER
dialogues.text: (rolling out) Boy, I've driven with deers, antelopes, even with bears strapped to my bumper. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: REDNECK DRIVER (cont'd) A sixty-five pound sack a fly shit like you ain’t gonna shake me a hell of difference.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Please, I'll do anything. I can pay you. I'll give you everything I have. He jams on the breaks. Les flies over the front hood. Mercedes can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les count out his money in front of the driver. The drive snatches the money, and walks around to the side of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Be gentle. Please.

dialogues.speaker: REDNECK DRIVER
dialogues.text: For eighty dollars? He hits a switch. The Cadillac CRASHES DOWN. Les is mortified. The redneck driver jumps into his truck, laughing. As he drives away, Mercedes approaches a distraught Les. After another huge swig from the magnum, offers him some champagne.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: This might help.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (harking back to his Dad's champagne toast) No, thanks, I already had some tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry about this, I feel like it was all my fault.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Nah, I should've given the car to the valet. (quiet) It's too bad about your friend.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: He was a jerk anyway. I don't know why I even hung around with him. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MERCEDES (cont'd) (beat) Why don't we get out of here?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: And go where? With the amount of money I have left in my pocket, we have two choices. Sit at a parking meter for twenty minutes, or go buy ourselves a paper. Mercedes laughs. It really isn't funny.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: I know a quiet spot, with plenty of free parking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dense forest. Cadillac Brougham hell. We can barely SEE the beams of the Cadillac's headlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car bounces along on a steep, narrow dirt mountain ro more suited for a horse or a 4x4. Whatever it is, it's not good for the car. Mercedes has moved beside Les. The radio is off. Les concentrates. Quiet. We hear the pounding of the shocks and the occasio branch scraping the car. And then a Mercedes HICCUP and a giggly “excuse me.”

dialogues.speaker: STRAIGHT AHEAD
dialogues.text: Bit by bit, the trees vanish. There's nothing but stars. The entire city sits below us, glowing like an expensive breach. It's a glorious sight. Les stops the car. They get out. Mercedes, clutching her now three quarters empty bottle of champagne, stares up at the stars. Merced is more than light headed. She's drunk. Les checks the condition of the car. It looks fine. Les gapes at Mercedes and the surroundings. It's a fantas come true. An awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: This is unbelievable up here. How did you find this place? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Someone I know used to take me here. (Les is shattered) Not a boyfriend. My father used to bring me here to show me how pretty the world could be if you could step away and see it from a distance. Les doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: (Cont'd) I haven't been here in a long time. She's about to sit in front of the car. Les leans

dialogues.speaker: THE TRUNK
dialogues.text: revealing

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (diving between her) Wait, wait one second. I havea blanket. It'll be more comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: You sure come prepared.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (ander his breath) Like a Boy Scout. into the car and releases the trunk lock.

dialogues.speaker: FLIPS OPEN
dialogues.text: an expensive set of GOLF CLUBS. Les searches the bag and pulls out a BLANKET. He races to the front of the car and spreads it out on th front hood. Les grins

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: (in between swigs) All we're missing is some soft romantic music. and whips into the car. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CADDIE
